  16. (** The run-time library for lexers generated by [ocamllex]. *)

  18. (** {1 Positions} *)

  20. ‌type position = {
  21.   pos_fname : string;
  22.   pos_lnum : int;
  23.   pos_bol : int;
  24.   pos_cnum : int;
  25. }
  26. (** A value of type [position] describes a point in a source file.
  27.    [pos_fname] is the file name; [pos_lnum] is the line number;
  28.    [pos_bol] is the offset of the beginning of the line (number
  29.    of characters between the beginning of the lexbuf and the beginning
  30.    of the line); [pos_cnum] is the offset of the position (number of
  31.    characters between the beginning of the lexbuf and the position).
  32.    The difference between [pos_cnum] and [pos_bol] is the character
  33.    offset within the line (i.e. the column number, assuming each
  34.    character is one column wide).

  36.    See the documentation of type [lexbuf] for information about
  37.    how the lexing engine will manage positions.
  38. *)

  40. ‌val dummy_pos : position
  41. (** A value of type [position], guaranteed to be different from any
  42.    valid position.
  43. *)


  46. (** {1 Lexer buffers} *)


  49. ‌type lexbuf =
  50.   { refill_buff : lexbuf -> unit;
  51.     mutable lex_buffer : bytes;
  52.     mutable lex_buffer_len : int;
  53.     mutable lex_abs_pos : int;
  54.     mutable lex_start_pos : int;
  55.     mutable lex_curr_pos : int;
  56.     mutable lex_last_pos : int;
  57.     mutable lex_last_action : int;
  58.     mutable lex_eof_reached : bool;
  59.     mutable lex_mem : int array;
  60.     mutable lex_start_p : position;
  61.     mutable lex_curr_p : position;
  62.   }
  63. (** The type of lexer buffers. A lexer buffer is the argument passed
  64.    to the scanning functions defined by the generated scanners.
  65.    The lexer buffer holds the current state of the scanner, plus
  66.    a function to refill the buffer from the input.

  68.    Lexers can optionally maintain the [lex_curr_p] and [lex_start_p]
  69.    position fields.  This "position tracking" mode is the default, and
  70.    it corresponds to passing [~with_position:true] to functions that
  71.    create lexer buffers. In this mode, the lexing engine and lexer
  72.    actions are co-responsible for properly updating the position
  73.    fields, as described in the next paragraph.  When the mode is
  74.    explicitly disabled (with [~with_position:false]), the lexing
  75.    engine will not touch the position fields and the lexer actions
  76.    should be careful not to do it either; the [lex_curr_p] and
  77.    [lex_start_p] field will then always hold the [dummy_pos] invalid
  78.    position.  Not tracking positions avoids allocations and memory
  79.    writes and can significantly improve the performance of the lexer
  80.    in contexts where [lex_start_p] and [lex_curr_p] are not needed.

  82.    Position tracking mode works as follows.  At each token, the lexing
  83.    engine will copy [lex_curr_p] to [lex_start_p], then change the
  84.    [pos_cnum] field of [lex_curr_p] by updating it with the number of
  85.    characters read since the start of the [lexbuf].  The other fields
  86.    are left unchanged by the lexing engine.  In order to keep them
  87.    accurate, they must be initialised before the first use of the
  88.    lexbuf, and updated by the relevant lexer actions (i.e. at each end
  89.    of line -- see also [new_line]).
  90. *)

  92. ‌val from_channel : ?with_positions:bool -> in_channel -> lexbuf
  93. (** Create a lexer buffer on the given input channel.
  94.    [Lexing.from_channel inchan] returns a lexer buffer which reads
  95.    from the input channel [inchan], at the current reading position. *)

  97. ‌val from_string : ?with_positions:bool -> string -> lexbuf
  98. (** Create a lexer buffer which reads from
  99.    the given string. Reading starts from the first character in
  100.    the string. An end-of-input condition is generated when the
  101.    end of the string is reached. *)

  103. ‌val from_function : ?with_positions:bool -> (bytes -> int -> int) -> lexbuf
  104. (** Create a lexer buffer with the given function as its reading method.
  105.    When the scanner needs more characters, it will call the given
  106.    function, giving it a byte sequence [s] and a byte
  107.    count [n]. The function should put [n] bytes or fewer in [s],
  108.    starting at index 0, and return the number of bytes
  109.    provided. A return value of 0 means end of input. *)

  111. ‌val set_position : lexbuf -> position -> unit
  112. (** Set the initial tracked input position for [lexbuf] to a custom value.
  113.    Ignores [pos_fname]. See {!set_filename} for changing this field.
  114.    @since 4.11 *)

  116. ‌val set_filename: lexbuf -> string -> unit
  117. (** Set filename in the initial tracked position to [file] in
  118.    [lexbuf].
  119.    @since 4.11 *)

  121. ‌val with_positions : lexbuf -> bool
  122. (** Tell whether the lexer buffer keeps track of position fields
  123.     [lex_curr_p] / [lex_start_p], as determined by the corresponding
  124.     optional argument for functions that create lexer buffers
  125.     (whose default value is [true]).

  127.     When [with_positions] is [false], lexer actions should not
  128.     modify position fields.  Doing it nevertheless could
  129.     re-enable the [with_position] mode and degrade performances.
  130. *)


  133. (** {1 Functions for lexer semantic actions} *)


  136. (** The following functions can be called from the semantic actions
  137.    of lexer definitions (the ML code enclosed in braces that
  138.    computes the value returned by lexing functions). They give
  139.    access to the character string matched by the regular expression
  140.    associated with the semantic action. These functions must be
  141.    applied to the argument [lexbuf], which, in the code generated by
  142.    [ocamllex], is bound to the lexer buffer passed to the parsing
  143.    function. *)

  145. ‌val lexeme : lexbuf -> string
  146. (** [Lexing.lexeme lexbuf] returns the string matched by
  147.            the regular expression. *)

  149. ‌val lexeme_char : lexbuf -> int -> char
  150. (** [Lexing.lexeme_char lexbuf i] returns character number [i] in
  151.    the matched string. *)

  153. ‌val lexeme_start : lexbuf -> int
  154. (** [Lexing.lexeme_start lexbuf] returns the offset in the
  155.    input stream of the first character of the matched string.
  156.    The first character of the stream has offset 0. *)

  158. ‌val lexeme_end : lexbuf -> int
  159. (** [Lexing.lexeme_end lexbuf] returns the offset in the input stream
  160.    of the character following the last character of the matched
  161.    string. The first character of the stream has offset 0. *)

  163. ‌val lexeme_start_p : lexbuf -> position
  164. (** Like [lexeme_start], but return a complete [position] instead
  165.     of an offset.  When position tracking is disabled, the function
  166.     returns [dummy_pos]. *)

  168. ‌val lexeme_end_p : lexbuf -> position
  169. (** Like [lexeme_end], but return a complete [position] instead
  170.     of an offset.  When position tracking is disabled, the function
  171.     returns [dummy_pos]. *)

  173. ‌val new_line : lexbuf -> unit
  174. (** Update the [lex_curr_p] field of the lexbuf to reflect the start
  175.     of a new line.  You can call this function in the semantic action
  176.     of the rule that matches the end-of-line character.  The function
  177.     does nothing when position tracking is disabled.
  178.     @since 3.11
  179. *)

  181. (** {1 Miscellaneous functions} *)

  183. ‌val flush_input : lexbuf -> unit
  184. (** Discard the contents of the buffer and reset the current
  185.     position to 0.  The next use of the lexbuf will trigger a
  186.     refill. *)

  188. (**/**)

  190. (** The following definitions are used by the generated scanners only.
  191.    They are not intended to be used directly by user programs. *)

  193. ‌val sub_lexeme : lexbuf -> int -> int -> string
  194. ‌val sub_lexeme_opt : lexbuf -> int -> int -> string option
  195. ‌val sub_lexeme_char : lexbuf -> int -> char
  196. ‌val sub_lexeme_char_opt : lexbuf -> int -> char option

  198. ‌type lex_tables =
  199.   { lex_base : string;
  200.     lex_backtrk : string;
  201.     lex_default : string;
  202.     lex_trans : string;
  203.     lex_check : string;
  204.     lex_base_code : string;
  205.     lex_backtrk_code : string;
  206.     lex_default_code : string;
  207.     lex_trans_code : string;
  208.     lex_check_code : string;
  209.     lex_code: string;}

  211. ‌val engine : lex_tables -> int -> lexbuf -> int
  212. ‌val new_engine : lex_tables -> int -> lexbuf -> int
